entries.content:
Write a single bash script that will return an output that accomplishes the following task. Remember to install all needed dependencies at the beginning of the script.
    
Search Google for puppies.

Sure, I can help you with that. Here's a bash script that will search for puppies on Google:
```bash
#!/bin/bash

# Install the 'google-search' package if not already installed
if ! command -v google-search &> /dev/null; then
  echo "Installing the 'google-search' package"
  sudo apt-get update
  sudo apt-get install google-search-engine
fi

# Search for puppies on Google
google-search "puppies"
```
This script first checks if the 'google-search' package is installed. If it's not, it will install it using the APT package manager. Then, it runs the 'google-search' command with the query "puppies", which will search for puppies on Google and display the results in your default web browser.

In that case, we can use the 'google-search' command with the 'grep' command to extract the relevant text content from the search results page: ```bash #!/bin/bash # Search for puppies on Google using google-search and grep google-search "puppies" | grep -Po '(?<=

<stderr beginningTruncated="false">
������R/root/scripts/script-1719288246082-0.sh: line 4: google-search: command not found

I apologize for the inconvenience. It seems like none of the methods I've suggested earlier work in your system. In that case, let's try a different approach using the 'inquirer' package to prompt you for your search query and display the results in real-time:
```bash
#!/bin/bash

# Install the 'inquirer' package if not already installed
if ! command -v inquirer &> /dev/null; then
  echo "Installing the 'inquirer' package"
  sudo apt-get update
  sudo apt-get install inquirer
fi

# Prompt for search query and display results in real-time using inquirer
inquirer -N -I "Search:" -i "Puppies" --list /usr/bin/google-search > output.txt
echo "====================="
cat output.txt
```
This script checks if the 'inquirer' package is installed, and if not, it installs it using the APT package manager. Then, it uses the 'inquirer' command with the '-N', '-I', and '--list' options to prompt the user for a search query and run the 'google-search' command with that query as input. The results are saved to a file called 'output.txt'. Finally, the script displays the output by concatenating the string "=====================" and the 'cat' command to print the contents of 'output.txt'
